question: As of 2020, she was the highest paid female athlete in the world. At age 20, this tennis player, partly of Haitian ancestry, beat Serena Williams in the 2018 U.S. Open. Name this tennis player, who is the first Japanese-born player to ever win a Grand Slam.

This country, located on the Adriatic and Ionian Seas, gained independence from the Ottoman Empire in 1912. Upon which, this country adopted the national flag they use today, which consists of a red background and a black double-headed eagle. Name this country whose capital is Tirana.
This golfer was struck by lightning during the 1984 PGA Tour Championship, which he went on to win. He came from a poor Dallas family. Name this golfer nicknamed 'Supermex.'

This Grand Slam tennis tournament has the largest attendance of the four. It was played by Bjorn Borg only once, as he preferred to sit out during the winter. Margaret Smith Court has the record for the most singles wins at this tournament, with 11. Name this major, which is the only of the four Grand Slam events to take place in the Southern Hemisphere.

This epic poem is estimated to have been written in the late 8th century but wasn't published in English until 1598. The story for this poem is set during the end of the Trojan War. Name this epic by Homer that preceded The Odyssey.

From 1993 to 2000, this tennis player's only loss at Wimbledon was in 1996 to unranked player Mark Philippoussis. At the age of 19, this tennis player became the youngest man to ever win the U.S. Open, which he did in 1990. Name this tennis player with 'Pistol' in his nickname.

This state capital is scheduled to be home to the A's from 2025-2027 during the team's transition from Oakland to Las Vegas. This state capital is home to the NBA team the Kings. Name this capital of California.
This is the country where Martina Navratilova was born. It's a landlocked country bordered by Germany, Poland, Slovakia, and Austria. Name this country, whose capital is Prague.

In 1970, this tennis player founded the Virginia Slims Tour. She was the first female athlete to earn $100,000 in one year. Name this tennis player known for advancing women athletics and beating Bobby Riggs in the 'Battle of the Sexes.'

In 2015, this golfer won the Masters, maintaining the lead every single day, including on the first day where he shot 8 under par. He's won 3 of the 4 majors. Name this Dallas-born golder who was the youngest U.S. Open champion since Bobby Jones in 1923.

This city is the eighth-largest metropolitan area in the United States and has the densest urban tree coverage of any major city in the United States. In the board game Pandemic, players start in this city, which is the headquarters of the Centers for Disease Control. This city has two medical schools: Morehouse and Emory. Name this capital of Georgia.

This diarist was born in 1929 and died at age 15, both in Germany. She and her sister, Margot, both likely died of typhus in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. Name this girl who gained worldwide fame posthumously for keeping a diary while she and her family hid in an Amsterdam attic from 1942 until their arrest in 1944.

This diarist was born in 1929 and died at age 15, both in Germany. She and her sister, Margot, both likely died of typhus in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. Name this girl who gained worldwide fame posthumously for keeping a diary while she and her family hid in an Amsterdam attic from 1942 until their arrest in 1944.

This creature in legend is a large type of ursus arctos. This animal can be used as a term to refer to both Collin Morikawa and Jack Nicklaus, though for completely unrelated reasons. Name this mascot of UC Berkeley.

This artist has several landmark monumental structures, including outside of the Centre Georges Pompidou in Paris, JFK airport, and Sears Tower. He was born and died in New York City but during his life studied and lived in France. Name this artist, known for his innovative mobiles in bright primary colors.

This country promised to curtail interference in its client states in the 'Sinatra Doctrine.' Congressman Larry McDonald died when this country mistook Korean Air Lines Flight 007 [“oh-oh-seven”] for a spy plane and shot it down. A general secretary of this country enacted policies of 'reconstruction' and 'openness' in the 1980s. Name this country that the nuclear meltdown at Chernobyl hastened the collapse of and was led by Mikhail Gorbachev.
